title: Clay-animated movie titles
content: I've tried searching the typophile archives (not working on my PowerBook!), asking friends, everything. I'm trying to identify and locate the movie that starts with a very surreal clay animated title sequence, with little clay balls, blocks and trees all marching or rolling or erupting into letters to form the names of the actors. Each name is a different sort of re-formation, from cylinders unrolling to show the letters, to craters in the ground erupting with letters, to waves of clay washing up and turning into letters. I seem to recall it's from the '60's, and it might be an Annette Funicello movie for all I know. I probably can't remember the movie because the titles are the best thing about it. It is a comedy, I'm sure. Does anyone remember that sequence, and know which movie it is?
author: crossgrove

[Bruce Bickford](http://web.archive.org/web/20150223073531/http:/brucebickford.com/bio.shtml) was clay animator who worked frequently with Frank Zappa during the early '70s.

[Here's a link](http://web.archive.org/web/20150223073531/http:/brucebickford.com/media/BruceClayWebQuick.mov) to one of his bizarre clay morphing from jungle to title animations (Quicktime).
How to Stuff a Wild Bikini (1965) - clay stuff by Art Clokey; the creator of Gumby - that's the movie you're looking for?

Zappa rocks.

Would love to find out what you're reffering to - sounds awesome

[Communication Design, Melbourne](http://web.archive.org/web/20150223073531/http:/www.solid-creative.com/)

Annette meets Gumby... think of the possibilities! ;-)

Carl,

Got here a couple hours late. Indeed it was Art Clokey. Many of the Gumby episodes had great animated title sequences as well:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/sets/1168574/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150223073531/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/sets/1168574/ "http://www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/sets/1168574/")

Oh, man. That Flickr link made me remember something from my childhood that probably had a hand in my obsession with letters.

I had some plaster letters just like these when I was about six years old:

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/53893098/in/set-1168574/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150223073531/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/53893098/in/set-1168574/ "http://www.flickr.com/photos/stewf/53893098/in/set-1168574/")

My dad salvaged some panels that were used at trade shows by the company he worked for. They were covered with letters like these in two sizes, around two inches tall, painted forest green. He pried them off and gave them to me. I used to spend hours playing with them. I'm sure they were a subconscious influence on [this](http://web.archive.org/web/20150223073531/http:/www.ms-studio.com/FontSales/refrigerator.html). I wonder whatever became of them.

(Sorry for going OT...)
One other thing: I did actually use them once for the animated title of an 8mm film I made when I was 13 or 14. Just like Art. :-)
I used to do stop-motion animation ... I should get back into it. Tedious but very rewarding (if that's possible)
